name: Ryan Johnson
comment info:
I noticed that the racial diversity in American neighborhoods has dramatically increased from 1980-2017. By 1980, the prevalence of predominantly white neighborhoods reduced by over half. In 2017, this trend of even race distribution continued until the frequency of white neighborhoods reduced by another quarter in respect to the 1980 census. Throughout these 37 years, the prevalence of predominantly black neighborhoods remained relatively constant. 

I wonder what caused this growth of racial diversity in American neighborhoods. I feel that this pattern could be linked to increasing economic and educational opportunities throughout our country. Due to the Obama administration’s 380 million dollar investment in education and infrastructure in 2014, many people gained access to education through a system independent from skin color. Because of this increased connectivity in education systems, many culturally diverse people developed experience in different fields. 

Growth in connectivity and infrastructure broke the chains linking race to social class and contributed to the growth of diversity in American neighborhoods nationwide.

name: Sean Hession
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
Headline: It’s a Diverse Day in the Neighborhood
    I notice immediately that the amount of neighborhoods which were completely white in 1980 was over a quarter of all neighborhoods. This shows the intense discrimination that persisted then. However, in the 2000 graph, it can be seen that the number of completely white neighborhoods dropped, and that the number of neighborhoods with about 50% nonwhite residents rose considerably. This trend persisted in the 2017 graph, where the same things happened as happened between 1980 and 2000. What this means is that whites and nonwhites are living in the same neighborhoods more than in 1980, as shown in the graphs. In fact, this is a trend I have noticed in my own neighborhood. 
    I was about four years old when my family first moved into my neighborhood. This neighborhood was small and quaint, and also probably about 90% white when we first moved in. This lack of diversity was very noticeable, and I only remember seeing a couple of nonwhite residents around me. However, over time, I began to notice change. Many new nonwhite families moved in. Now, there is probably about a 65-70% percent white population, which is still not the most diverse, but it is a much bigger step towards progress from 90% ten years before. Seeing this in my local community, I wonder if others have noticed this around them. Personally, I hope they have because this positive increase in diversity will lead to more respect between races and a better world.

name: Shubh Khanna
comment info:
Title: Shifting Demographics, Shifting Distributions

The graphs highlight the shifting landscape in the diversity of American neighborhoods: more censuses report diverse neighborhoods and fewer all-white neighborhoods. Looking at the three graphs, we can notice that over time, more census tracts are in the center of the distribution. This increased diversity in American neighborhoods, however, is not attributed to dwindling non-white, segregated neighborhoods. Rather, most neighborhoods that have become more diverse have shifted from the right side to the center, with non-whites moving into previously white-dominated neighborhoods. 

This change is extremely important in understanding shifting demographics and economic opportunities for difference races. A topic discussed in a recent NPR podcast is the importance of housing segregation – or a lack thereof – in economic mobility. During the middle of the 20th century, the government segregated housing, resulting in lost economic mobility for non-whites and an inability to hold appreciable assets. That is why as the descendents of the white households used their assets to send their children to college, non-whites suffered. Today, African-American income is about 60% of average white incomes, but African-American wealth is about 5% of white wealth. 

As such, understanding racial diversity in American neighborhoods is extremely important, and the increasing diversity is a positive indicator for future wealth equality.

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Shubh Khanna --

Thank you for analysis of these graphs.  You noticed that the shift was from mostly white neighborhoods to more diverse neighborhoods!  
There were 11,155,486 census tracts in the 2010 US Census.  Each tract has 2,500 – 8,000 residents.  How many tracts is 1%?  How many people could have been in mostly white neighborhoods, but are now in diverse neighborhoods?
Please come back tomorrow to get the link to the article that included these graphs.  There is a discuss about the movement from not diverse neighborhoods to more diverse neighborhoods.
